Take a look at who publishes The New Atlantis -- the Witherspoon Institute, the Ethics and Public Policy Center -- and then say with a straight face it has no real editorial agenda. The New Atlantis is funded by some of the most right-wing, fundamentalist folks out there.

To ekeizer4: A few years ago I read a series of 3 articles on evolution and genetics and was flabbergasted how misleading they were.

And now I see why. I had no idea where the funding came from and was naive enough to think it was nothing but poorly written articles.

I feel like the recommendations at the end are still deeply embeded within the American political spectrum, so I just wanted to add some examples further outside of it that I like.

The New Atlantis: runs the gambit of views on science's role in society, and often includes articles of social criticism unrelated to technological advance. No real editorial agenda. http://www.thenewatlantis.com/

The World Press: samples investigative journalism and editorial criticism from different geographic regions. The emphasis is on giving readers a strong sense of under-the-radar issues of the day from across the world. Contributors lean to outsider/non-mainstream opinions; hostility towards one country or another is common. http://www.worldpress.org/

Three Quarks Daily: A blog that has become very popular among self-proclaimed intellectuals for collecting and sharing articles for sheer intellectual interest. Tends to focus on liberal arts but often shares things of interest to public policy such as pedagogy and psychology. http://www.3quarksdaily.com/

Redistribution by taxes has the effect of stimulating demand and thus improving

During the Great Depression, very high rates applied to households earning over a million, and in 40-41 earning over 5 billion, to help pay for the stimulus programs. Besides, until Bush, we paid for our wars with taxes. The French court seems to be ignorant of economic evidence.

I don't know about French constitution or law enough to comment on the decision itself.  However, I do have enough European friends and read enough articles to say yeah, it was a bit surprising that there are only 1500 people who make 1 mm euros because I am pretty sure my previous company had more people that made more than $1mm last year!  Then again, I know that in France or Italy, you don't have to be making millions to live a half way decent life.  As a matter of fact, you don't even need to make the so-called six figure salary to live a comfortable middle class life, have access to the best healthcare (ranked by WHO), and send your kids to college while enjoying some of the most beautiful places, richest history, and best food in the world as simply part of daily routine!  I only wish I had learned French in school and that my parents had sent me to continental Europe to study (instead of united states.)

Finally thought of MEIOSIS, which goes from diplOID to haplOID, instead of MITOSIS, where plOIDy stays the same.. Yup, 'ploidy' is a real word.

My favorite clue was 103A, Division of biology for MITOSIS. My favorite new word was ROOTLE.  Compared to the many too-easy Sundays we've had lately, this was a very respectable puzzle. Saturday's quintbuster was a tough act to follow!

I didn't grow up around guns, but I have relatives who did--they grew up hunting and later served in the military. Visiting with them, they taught me the rudiments of gun safety; we spent some lovely hours doing target practice.

The real issue in the Newtown case is about mental illness; the shooter stole his mother's guns--she had a valid gun license.

Lots of gun owners are sane and reasonable people who do not commit crimes. Yet, this attempt to draw publicity makes it appear that owners of gun permits are all to be hounded, as though they are not law-abiding citizens.

Yes, the records are public; anyone can access them. That doesn't mean, though, that a newspaper should publicize. I think a better article would have provided debate on gun control and mention, perhaps, that gun licenses are a matter of public record, but without violating anyone's privacy.

Rima: thanks for those articles on adoption for U.S.-born children.  They were most enlightening although some of the assertions made by those who've had a run of bad luck with our adoption system provided necessary balance. This issue is certainly not my strong-suit.

Nobody denies that countries can make their own rules regarding adoption. If Russia wants to ban foreign adoptions, however misguided a decision that might be, fine . . . but it is unfair and blatantly cruel to both adoptive parents and the orphans to terminate the adoptions that are already in process . . . situations alluded to in the articles where parents and children have met and hugged each other and have begun to bond. Let the 200-250 adoptions underway go through, and then they can impose their ban afterwards if they are really determined to put the ban into effect.

With respect to why don't some Americans adopt domestically, there dozens if not hundreds of reasons which have been discussed at length in discussion forums in recent days at many news sites . . . every adoptive parent has complex and multifaceted reasons for taking the path they have chosen.
It's human trafficking by governments instead of gangsters.

I am also tired of hearing the difficulties and pain the parents endure when they adopt. Ok, I can understand the need to vent, but...

NONE of that pain justifies why they should be able to adopt or why adoption should be made easier for them. It validates the notion that too many adoptive parents are self-serving and detracts from responding to children's needs.

Adoption is NOT a good thing. Adoption is a possible response to a HORRIBLE situation, the CHILD's situation. We should NOT be cheering at every adoption. It's a terrible loss for the child at many levels.

I understand that many couples suffer from infertility or being unable to realize their own dreams and aspirations, but that also doesn't justify why they should be able to adopt. It would be wonderful if everyone could have their dreams come true. It's great when it happens, but life is also about coping when we don't get what we most desire.

Adoption is about the children. They have no choice or voice about what's in their future. They deserve to have people with a voice advocating on the CHILDREN's behalf, not on the adoptive parents' behalf. The adoptive parents always have a choice to NOT adopt and to look for life's fulfillment in other ways. There are many ways to help these children without adopting them. These children have no choice.

I'm not necessarily against international adoption. But I'm kind of tired of hearing the news stories on tv about parents who are hurting because they may not get to see their Russian kids. Russia is a sovereign nation that has the right to enact laws. From their point of view, they are protecting THEIR children (whether or not the real reason is revenge on a law that the United States enacted directed at Russians who are supposedly human right violators.) Americans are sometimes hypocrite. I wonder how congress here would act if Russians (or citizens from another country) suddently started adopting American children en masse. Furthermore, I never understood why some couples choose to adopt from Russia while there are many American children in need of homes. Maybe, the author of this article can answer that question.

Instead of bleeding economy with non-discretionary cuts, wouldn't it be better to lend it a healing touch by resorting to judicious and progressive tax increase, focused on the paying capacity and consumption needs of different strata of society? That is, allow social equity while working out the tax-code reforms.

That 80% number is a farce. The effective rate tehn was lower than it is today thanks to a tax code that is so complicated the rich can say they are paying 80% when in the end it is 13% and no one understands completely how it gets there. You will have 10 specialists (or more) working on an ultra wealthy return. It takes a team. And no one individual will understand the full return much less David Underwood. The only answer, the only answer, is eliminate all deductions and tax credits so that we all know what everyone pays and how everyone is (secretly) rewarded. Tax credits are kickbacks. Rewards for campaign contributions. You want to campaign finance reform that is legal? Eliminate tax credits.

Once we understand what people pay, then we can decide what a fair rate should be. Playing with rates in a tax code as complicated as exists is only a delusion that makes people who want social reform feel good. There MIGHT be a small impact on the ultra wealthy by raising top rates and rates on capital gains but don't bet on it. There will be a huge shift to TAX FREE municipal bonds. If not there, it will be some other of the countless, countless, tax credits, deductions or exceptions. The average American has no clue the mess and size of our tax code. The code printed on 8x11 paper in font this size, double sided, cannot be lifted by the average person, much less read and understood.

You raise an issue that needs some attention in the course of discussion of taxing capital gains at ordinary income rates.  I favor this approach, also, but I believe there should be a floor to protect middle class people who have invested in the stock market to secure their retirement.  Tax all capital gains in excess of $XXXXX.00 as ordinary income.  Additionally, or alternatively, tax all capital gains on taxpayers having Adjusted Gross Income of $1,000,000.  This approach would not only protect the middle class, but would conceivably raise a lot more in taxes than simply raising ordinary income tax rates on income over $250,000.

When I first stared paying federal income taxes it was a graduated system. The wealthy paid in excess of 80% as I recall. But somehow they always seemed to stay wealthy.

For as long as I can remember, that system was derided as being unfair to the wealthy and of course leading us to Socialism. But as I moved up the economic ladder I also paid a higher rate of taxes, and along the way, more of them.

Then the system changed and the wealthy got their rates lowered, they told us it would make the economy grow. But those wealthy did not build new factories, or fund new discoveries, they used the extra money to buy castles in Ireland, and estates on Lake Geneva. Of course they did put some people to work on their yachts, and in the gardens.

Indeed the tax code is unfair. Those heirs to Cargill and WalMart for instance collect hundreds of thousands of dollars a day in dividends. And when they sell some of their inherited equities, they pay the capital gins tax of 15% which to them is most likely less than they pay their accountants.

For those of us who will have to sell our equities along the way in our retirement that amounts to a bigger percentage of our incomes, so will lower our discretionary spending somewhat.

I have noted that over the years, the wealthy seem to have ways to get tax breaks. These are the people that can afford a good accountant, and a lawyer, and have personal access to their elected officials.

So who is going to lead this reform?
Women are in danger in any country.  My heart goes out to this woman's family.

Because of the brutal nature of the case, many people throughout India have taken to the streets demanding the death sentence for the perpetrators and the stoppage of violence against women. I can understand their anger and frustration. Although I cannot be with them to show my solidarity, I am mentally with them to support their cause. As members of civilized society, we must stop such violence against women.

I do not understand why women are mistreated in a country where the ideals of goddess were championed in religion. Scriptures extolling the greatness and virtues of the divine feminine abound, and yet respect for women is utterly lacking.

I strongly believe that respect for and appreciation of women should start in the home. Men in a home where women are mistreated or viewed as sex objects, tend to show their aggression toward other women. This is what seems to have happened two weeks ago in the capital city of India.

Parents of boys who committed such brutal sexual attacks on the girl should be held equally responsible. If the government of India passes a law to hold parents liable for the actions of their sons, perhaps these parents would teach their children to show respect, compassion and goodwill toward women, and such heinous crimes would not take place.
